description.p: A female half-orc lumbers through the forest, her primal tattoos glistening in the light of the moon. A child from her tribe had seen a group of hobgoblins cutting lumber from their sacred grove of trees. Slicing her hand, the half-orc used her dark blood to inscribe a glyph on a the hilt of her greatclub. The weapon began to pulse with a deep green aura as she ventured forth to deal with the foolish hobgoblins that had dared profane the sacred grove of her tribe. For desecrating the holy place of her ancestors, they would pay with their lives.

A hunched over, elderly halfling grips his necklace as he faces down the massive ogre who had come to threaten his village. The necklace, made from the finger bones of the villiage’s previous shamans, allowed their spirits to empower his aging body. Drawing upon the power of his predecessors, he could once again move with the vigor of his youth. Quick as lightning, he struck the ogre’s head with the ceremonial quarterstaff that marked him as the elder of his people. As his foe’s body slumped to the ground, he reflected on his time defending his people as their champion. Soon his time would come to an end, and his body would rejoin the earth. However, his spirit would live on, joining the previous elders, providing aid forever.

In the dark of night, a thin elvish woman used her connection to magic of creation to conduct a dark ritual on a stolen lock of hair. The next morning, far across town, the village fool came down with a mysterious illness, and within hours he had succumbed to the strange pox. The townsfolk suspected dark magic was at play, but after a few days they buried the fool and moved on. The man who had dared to insult the crone had paid the price for his sharp words.

Every living thing, plants, animals, and even the landscape, is suffused with the magic of creation. Shamans are the rare few that learn to draw upon that natural energy that flows through all life. After opening themselves up to this power they are able to mold this primal energy to enhance and change the shape of their bodies, place strange curses on their foes, shape the landscape, wield the raw power of the elements, and heal the sick. The practice of shamanistic magic is ancient in origin, and traces its roots back to the dawn of creation. Since the beginning, shamans have passed their teachings and traditions from one generation to the next in an unending chain of sages.

Some say that shamanistic magic is older then the divine magic of the gods, and more powerful then the arcane magic of the most well-studied wizards. However, those that understand this power are rare. Shamans overwhelmingly embrace the old ways of the world. They find themselves uncomfortable in civilized society, instead preferring to dwell in the wild where their connection to nature is strongest.

Unlike most spellcasters, shamans don’t come to learn their magic through study or devotion. Through meditation and introspection they learn to tap into the raw energy of creation innate in all living things. Once they open themselves, their connection to the power of the natural world is intense, and shamans constantly run the risk of being overwhelmed by the magic they wield. Many who attempt to follow the way of the shaman are consumed by the life-energy they draw into themselves, irrevocably transforming into large trees or stalagmites that vaguely resemble their original form.

But, for the few that strike a balance between themselves and this power, they are able to wield the primal magic that was instrumental in the creation of the multiverse. They walk the land, mediating the eternal struggle between humanoid races and the wild beast and plants of the world.

When creating your shaman, consider how you came to be a conduit for the power of creation. Were you trained from birth to be the elder of your tribe, destined to bear the power that comes with the spiritual support of your ancestors? Did a terrible hag steal you away and raise you in her ways, teaching you the secrets of curses and hex magic? Or did you study under an ancient hermit, learning to manipulate the energy present in all things in order to heal the broken?

Whatever your origin, consider how your relationship to the natural world effects your character. Do you gently beseech the power of nature? Or do you violently wrest control of the primeval creative energies around you?

You can make a shaman quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Wisdom your highest ability score followed by Constitution. Second, choose the hermit background. Third, select the shillelagh and vicious mockery cantrips along with the 1st-level spells entangle and heroism.
As a shaman, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per shaman level after 1st
Weapons: Simple weapons, blow guns, nets.
Skills: Choose two from Animal Handling, Arcana, Insight, Medicine, Nature, Performance, or Religion

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a quarterstaff or (b) any simple weapon
(a) a shortbow and 20 arrows or (b) 5 javelins
(a) a priest’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack
Leather armor and a Shamanistic Fetish.

description.p: If your group uses this optional rule, here’s what you need to know if you choose the shaman as one of your classes.
Ability Score Minimum. You must have an Wisdom score of at least 13 to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already a shaman.

Proficiencies Gained. If shaman isn’t your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level in shaman: light armor, shields, simple weapons, and one skill from the shaman skill list.

Spellcasting. If you have the Spellcasting feature and the Primal Magic feature from the shaman, you can use the spell slots you gain from Primal Magic to cast spells you know or have prepared from classes with the Spellcasting feature, and you can use the spell slots you gain from the Spellcasting feature to cast any shaman spells you know.

setters.set: If shaman isn’t your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level in shaman: light armor, shields, simple weapons, and one skill from the shaman skill list.

description.p: You have learned to draw upon your connection to primordial power of nature to cast spells. See chapter 11 of the Player’s Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting and the end of this class description for the shaman spell list.

You know two cantrips of your choice from the shaman spell list at the end of this class description You learn additional shaman cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Shaman table.

The Shaman table shows how many spell slots you have, and the level of these spell slots. All of your spell slots are of the same level. To cast one of your shaman spells of 1st-level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest.
For example, as a 5th level shaman, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell cure wounds, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.
description.h5: SPELLS KNOWN OF 1ST LEVEL AND HIGHER
description.p: When you gain your Primal Magic at 1st level, you learn two 1st-level spells of your choice from the shaman spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Shaman table shows when you learn more shaman spells of your choice of 1st-level and higher. A spell you choose must be of a level no higher than what’s shown in the table’s Slot Level column for your level. When you reach 6th level, for example, you learn a new shaman spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd-level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the shaman spells you know and replace it with another spell from the shaman spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your shaman spells, so you use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a shaman spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
You can use a shamanistic fetish as a spellcasting focus for your shaman spells. See the Shamanistic Fetishes note below for a list of objects that count as a shamanistic fetish.

div.p: When a shaman casts a spell, they must be careful not to be consumed by the power they draw upon. For this reason, their spellcasting focus, known as a shamanistic fetish, must be a mundane item of personal significance worth at least 1 gp.

description.p: At the end of a long rest, you can perform a short meditation, and replace one shaman spell you know from your Primal Magic feature with another spell from the shaman spell list of a level equal to, or lower then, your Slot Level.
You can cast any shaman spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.

At the end of a long rest, you can perform a short meditation, and replace one shaman spell you know from your Primal Magic feature with another spell from the shaman spell list of a level equal to, or lower then, your Slot Level.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you can perform a short meditation, and replace one shaman spell you know from your Primal Magic feature with another spell from the shaman spell list of a level equal to, or lower then, your Slot Level.

description.p: Shamans must focus on a powerful aspect of themselves in order avoid being consumed by the power they channel. This focus, known as your sacred technique, grants you certain innate bonuses depending on your choice of focus. At 1st level, select a sacred technique from the options below.
Body. This sacred technique draws power through your physical form. Your hit point maximum to increases by 1 and increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class.

Mind. This sacred technique uses your intellect to dominate the power you channel. When you make an Intelligence-based ability check or saving throw, you can choose to use your Wisdom score in place of Intelligence.

Heart. This sacred technique channels primal power through your most powerful emotions. When you make a saving throw, you can choose to have advantage, or disadvantage, on the roll. However, the next saving throw you make is made with the opposite effect. For example, if you gave yourself advantage on a saving throw, the next saving throw you make is made with disadvantage.

Soul. This sacred technique balanced the raw primal power with the serenity of your soul, granting you a serene measure of protection. While you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your armor class is equal to 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier.

description.p: You have learned the shamanistic art of creating totems through which you channel primal power. These totems allow you to use specific powerful magic abilities without the risk of being overwhelmed. At 2nd level, you learn two totems of your choice from the list at the end of this class description. A shaman’s totems are unique to them. Some appear as shimmering tattoos, and others as small animal carvings that adorn their weapons and clothing. You learn additional totems of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Totems Known column of the Shaman Table.
At the end of a long rest, you can choose one of the totems you know and replace it with another totem of your choice that you meet the prerequisites for.

Listed below are the totems available to a shaman. If a totem has prerequisites, you must meet them to learn it. A level prerequisite refers to your shaman level. You can learn the totem at the same time that you meet its prerequisites.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you can choose one of the totems you know and replace it with another totem of your choice that you meet the prerequisites for.

description.p: Upon reaching 3rd level, you adopt a spirituality. Your spirituality dictates the how you interact with the primal forces of nature and the way in which you manifest your power. Most shamans learn their spirituality directly from a mentor, community elders, or a powerful creature of the natural world. However, some shamans have been known to develop their own spirituality in the absence of a mentor.
Choose one of the following Spiritualities detailed at the end of this class description: Curse Binder, Earth Shaker, Spirit Warrior, Storm Caller, Wild Heart, or Witch Doctor.

Each Spirituality has a list of spells that you gain at the shaman levels noted in the Spirituality description. These spells count as shaman spells for you, but they don’t count against your number of Spells Known. Spells gained from this feature cannot be replaced when you gain a level in this class or with your Spell Versatility feature.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Starting at 11th level, your spiritual connection with the natural world deepens, allowing you to briefly unleash the raw power of creation in overwhelming ways. Choose one 6th-level spell from the shaman spell list. You can cast this Primeval Conduit spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

As you gain levels in this class, you gain more shaman spells of your choice that can be cast in this way: one 7th-level spell at 13th level, one 8th-level spell at 15th level, and one 9th-level spell at 17th level. You regain all uses of your Primeval Conduit spells when you finish a long rest.
At the end of a long rest, you can replace one of your Primeval Conduit spells with another shaman spell of the same level, instead of using your Spell Versatility feature.

sheet.description: You can cast your Primeval Conduit spells once each per long rest. At the end of a long rest, you can replace one of your Primeval Conduit spells with another shaman spell of the same level, instead of using your Spell Versatility feature.

description.p: You have gained mastery over the power that once threatened to consume you, and you can siphon energy from the world around you to replenish your reserves of primal power. Upon reaching 20th level, as an action, you can draw upon the life-essence of the surrounding landscape and immediately regain one of your expended Primal Magic spell slots.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: You can immediately regain one of your expended Primal Magic spell slots.

description.p: While most shamans draw upon life giving energy of creation to create and heal, some twist their connection, using it to hinder and hex their foes. Curse Binders are masters of this foul side of shamanism. Often the students of vile hags, or dark beings from the shadowfell, these dark shamans use forbidden techniques to twist a creature’s own life essence against them. Their familiarity with dark magic allows Curse Binders to protect themselves against hexes, blights, and other dark magics they confront.

You learn to twist a creature’s life essence in harmful ways. Starting at 3rd level, when a creature you can see within 30 feet makes an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on their roll.
You may use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When a creature you can see within 30 feet makes an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can impose disadvantage on their roll.

description.p: Upon adopting this spirituality at 3rd level, you learn to twist the life essence of a creature, hindering their abilities. As an action, you can choose to inflict one of the following primal curses on a creature you can see within 30 feet. These curses last for 1 minute, unless you are incapacitated or end the curse as a bonus action. If you curse a second creature, any curse effects immediately end for the previous creature.
As you reach certain shaman levels you can have more curses active at once; two at 11th level, and three at 17h level. A single creature can only be under the effect of one curse.

Curse of Binding. You force a creature to make a Strength saving throw. On failed save, its movement speed is reduced by a number of feet equal to five times your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 5 feet). The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each turn, ending the effect on a success.

Curse of Draining. You force a creature to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 1d4 necrotic damage and cannot regain hit points. At the end of each of its turns the creature must repeat the saving throw, taking an additional 1d4 necrotic damage on a failed save, and ending the effects of this curse on a success.

Curse of Lethargy. You force a creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must subtract your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) from its attack rolls. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

sheet.description: You can choose to inflict one of the following primal curses on a creature you can see within 30 feet. These curses last for 1 minute, unless you are incapacitated or end the curse as a bonus action. If you curse a second creature, any curse effects immediately end for the previous creature.

You can choose to inflict one of the following primal curses on a creature you can see within 30 feet. These curses last for 1 minute, unless you are incapacitated or end the curse as a bonus action. You can have two curses active at a time. If you curse a third creature, any curse effects immediately end for the previous creature.

You can have three curses active at a time. If you curse a fourth creature, any curse effects immediately end for the previous creature.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, your practice of twisted magic has made your abilities more powerful. When you damage a creature with a cantrip or primal curse you gain a bonus to the damage roll equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1).

sheet.description: When you damage a creature with a cantrip or primal curse you gain a +{{wis-mod:min-one}} bonus to the damage roll.

description.p: Beginning at 10th level, you can ward yourself against magical effects. At the end of each long rest choose one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, necrotic, poison, psychic, radiant, or thunder. You gain resistance to that damage type until the end of your next long rest.
Attacks made with silvered weapons ignore any damage resistances you gain from this ability.

sheet.description: At the end of each long rest choose one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, necrotic, poison, psychic, radiant, or thunder. You gain resistance to that damage type until the end of your next long rest. Attacks made with silvered weapons ignore any damage resistances you gain from this ability.

description.p: You have reached the pinnacle of foul shamanism, and learned to conjure spirits of darkness. Upon reaching 14th level, you can cast create undead as a 6th-level spell, without providing any of the material components or expending a spell slot. Spirits rise out of the ground in the shape of the undead you summon. They are under your control until the end of your next long rest, or until they are destroyed.
Once you use this ability you must complete a long rest before you can cast create undead in this way again.

sheet.description: You can cast create undead as a 6th-level spell, without providing any of the material components or expending a spell slot. Spirits rise out of the ground in the shape of the undead you summon. They are under your control until the end of your next long rest, or until they are destroyed.

description.p: Since the dawn of time mortals have communed with the spirits of the deceased. Turning to them for guidance in the present, stories of the past, and glimpses of the future. Some shamans allow the spirits to work through their bodies, granting them the martial prowess of warriors long dead. Known as Spirit Warriors, these shamans are often found guarding sacred places, hidden from civilization.

Sprit Warriors make stalwart allies and terrible foes, and woe to those who would rouse these ancient protectors to action. Fighting in tandem with the spirits of the world around them, Spirit Warriors gain enhanced physical and spiritual abilities, some which may seem unnatural.

td.em: contact other plane, steel wind strike XGtE

description.p: When you adopt this Spirituality at 3rd level, the spirits lend you their skill with the armaments of war. You gain proficiency with medium armor and martial weapons.
Spirit Warriors are particular about what weapons and armor they use, and will go to great lengths to avoid using weapons and armor forged through the toil of industry.

sheet.description: Spirit Warriors will go to great lengths to avoid using weapons and armor forged through the toil of industry.

description.p: You have learned the secret technique of the Spirit Warrior, special glyphs, that when inscribed upon a weapon, grant its wielder incredible power. Starting at 3rd level, when you finish a long rest, you touch one weapon of your choice, inscribing it with one of the glyphs below. Only Spirit Warriors know how to draw out the potential of these glyphs, for anyone else the weapon functions as normal. The glyph you choose lasts until the end of your next long rest.

Glyph of Binding. This glyph draws out the full potential of your physical strength. While wielding this weapon you have advantage on any Strength (Athletics) check you make to grapple a creature, and you have advantage on any attack rolls you make targeting a creature that is grappled by you.

Glyph of Draining. This glyph can drain the life force of others to restore your vitality. When you roll a 20 on an attack roll with this weapon, the creature takes an additional 2d6 necrotic damage. You regain hit points equal to the extra necrotic damage dealt. This ability has no effect on constructs or undead creatures.

Glyph of Wounding. This glyph allows the weapon to inflict deep, grievous, wounds upon your foes. When you deal damage to a creature with this weapon, the creature cannot regain hit points until the beginning of your next turn.

description.p: The spirits that guide you have imbued you with the heart of a warrior. Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Your familiarity with spirits beyond the veil grants you an increased resilience when facing death. Beginning at 10th level, you can sacrifice your own life essence to resist the grasp of death. When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to expend one of your Hit Dice, causing you to drop to 1 hit point instead.

sheet.description: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to expend one of your Hit Dice, causing you to drop to 1 hit point instead.

description.p: Upon reaching 14th level, you can allow the spirits to take full control of your body. As a bonus action on your turn, you can enter a possessed state that lasts for one minute, or until you are reduced to 0 hit points. While in this possessed state your movement speed is doubled, you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks, and your melee weapon attacks deal an additional 2d6 necrotic damage on hit.
Once you use this ability you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend one of your Primal Magic spell slots to use it again.

div.p: Talk to your Dungeon Master about re-flavoring the weapons and armor in the Player’s Handbook to fit the Spirit-Warrior’s theme: a breastplate made of heartwood or a greataxe with an obsidian blade. However, if you choose not to follow this theme, there are no mechanical draw-backs for using normal metal armor and weapons.

sheet.description: You can enter a possessed state that lasts for one minute, or until you are reduced to 0 hit points. While in this possessed state your movement speed is doubled, you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks, and your melee weapon attacks deal an additional 2d6 necrotic damage on hit.

description.p: Almost every town and city has folk tales of humanoids raised by animals, learning to live in tandem with beasts of the land instead of with their own kind. Stories of these feral children are used to reinforce the importance of society. While most of these tales are nothing more then local legends with no basis in reality, some are inspired by the bestial shamans known as Wild Hearts.

These shamans reject humanoid civilization and set out into the wilds, looking to live in harmony with animals. They use their connection with primal magic to assume the form of great and terrible beasts, and serve as protectors of local wildlife. Wild Hearts will go to any lengths necessary to protect the creatures that they view as part of their pack.

Upon adopting this spirituality at 3rd level, you primal connection to the wilds enhances your physical abilities. Choose one of the following features of your choice that best reflects the beasts you seek to emulate.
Agile Adaptation. Your movement speed increases by 10 feet, and you ignore the effects of mundane difficult terrain.
Alpine Adaptation. You gain a 30 foot climb speed, and you can use your reaction to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to your shaman level.
Aquatic Adaptation. You gain a 30 foot swim speed, and you can hold your breath underwater for up to one hour.
Your movement speed increases by 10 feet, and you ignore the effects of mundane difficult terrain.

description.p: Your kinship with the animals of the land allows you to take on the form of a great beast. Starting at 3rd level, you can expend one of your Primal Magic spell slots to transform into a great beast, using the Great Beast stat bock, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places. When you transform you choose one bestial trait from the list at the end of this spirituality. You determine the appearance of your great beast, but its appearance has no effect on its abilities. While you are transformed the following rules apply:

ul.li: You use the Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores of the great beast, but you retain your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies.

You assume the hit points and Hit Dice of the great beast. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert because you dropped to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form.

You can’t cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn’t break your concentration on a spell you’ve already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell.

You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is capable of doing so. However, you can’t use any of your special senses unless your new form also has that sense.
Any equipment you are wearing or carrying merges into your great beast form. Equipment that merges with your great beast form has no effect while transformed.

description.p: Your great beast form lasts for one hour. You then revert to your normal form unless you expend another Primal Magic spell slot. You revert to your normal form if you use a bonus action to do so, fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.

sheet.description: You can expend one of your Primal Magic spell slots to transform into a great beast for up to 1 hour.

description.p: When you use your Primal Wild Shape to transform into a great beast, you determine some of the beast’s characteristics. Each time you transform, choose the appropriate number of bestial traits from the list below.
Aggressive. As a bonus action, the great beast can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.
Amphibious. The great beast can breathe air and water.
Aquatic. The great beast gains a swim speed of 40 feet.

Charge. If the great beast moves at least 20 feet in a straight line toward a target and then hits it with a Rend attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 1d6 slashing damage. If the target is a creature it must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your shaman spell save DC or be knocked prone.
Keen Sight. The great beast has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.
Pack Tactics. The great beast has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the its allies is within 5 feet of the creature, and the ally isn’t incapacitated.
Large. The great beast becomes a Large creature.
Powerful Build. The great beast counts as one size larger when determining the weight it can push, drag, lift, or carry.

Savage Bite. If the great beast hits a creature that is the same size, or smaller, with a bite attack, the creature is grappled (escape DC is equal to your shaman spell save DC). Until the grapple ends, the target is restrained, and the great beast cannot bite another target.
Standing Leap. The great beast’s long jump is 15 feet, and its high jump is 10 feet, with or without a running start.
Sure Footed. The great beast has advantage on saving throws to resist being forcibly moved or knocked prone.

sheet.description: When you transform you choose {{bestial-trait:count}} from the list.

description.p: You attack with the speed and accuracy of an apex predator. Starting at 6th level, when you are in great beast form and you take the Bite or Rend action, you can make an additional Bite or Rend attack as part of the same action. The primal magic you draw upon to transform suffuses your bestial form. Your attacks in great beast form count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistance.
In addition, when you use your Primal Wild Shape you choose two bestial traits for your great beast form.

sheet.description: When you are in great beast form and you take the Bite or Rend action, you can make an additional Bite or Rend attack as part of the same action. Your attacks in great beast form count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistance

description.p: Beginning at 10th level, you can draw on your pain to fuel your fury. As a bonus action, you can expend one of your Hit Dice, immediately gaining hit points equal to the number rolled + your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1).
Any hit points you gain from this ability that exceed your hit point maximum become temporary hit points.
In addition, when you use your Primal Wild Shape you choose three bestial traits for your great beast form.

sheet.description: You immediately gaint 1d8 + {{wis-mod:min-one}} hit points. Any hit points you gain from this ability that exceed your hit point maximum become temporary hit points.

description.p: You have mastered your great beast form, drawing out its true potential. When you transform into a great beast, its Strength score becomes 20, and the damage of your Bite and Rend attacks increase by 1d6.
In addition, when you use your Primal Wild Shape you choose four bestial traits for your great beast form.

sheet.description: When you transform into a great beast, its Strength score becomes 20, and the damage of your Bite and Rend attacks increase by 1d6.

description.p: When all other options for help have been exhausted, nobles and peasants alike will turn to the medicine men of old in their time of need. Those who practice ancient healing ceremonies and traditional herbal remedies are known as Witch-Doctors. Masters of stimulating the life essence of creatures to induce healing, they are often found wandering the land offering aid to those in desperate need.

Upon adopting this spirituality at 3rd level, you learn to manipulate the life energy in others to stimulate natural healing. As a bonus action on your turn, you can touch one creature and heal them. They regain a number of hit points equal to 1d10 + your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1).
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: You can touch one creature and heal them. They regain 1d10 + {{wis-mod:min-one}} hit points.

description.p: You have learned to transfer the benefits of your totems to others. Starting at 3rd level, at the end of a long rest, you can bestow up to half your totems (rounded up) upon other willing creatures that you touch. The benefits of these totems last until the end of your next long rest, at which point the totem abilities end for the creature and return to you.
You can grant each totem to only one creature at a time, and a creature can only gain the benefits of one totem.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you can bestow up to half your totems (rounded up) upon other willing creatures that you touch.

description.p: Upon reaching 6th level, you learn to empower your weapon strikes with your own life essene. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 radiant damage. This additional radiant damage increases to 2d8 at 14th level.

sheet.description: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {{empowered-strike:damage-dice}}d8 radiant damage.

description.p: Beginning at 10th level, your spirit is enhanced when you enhance your allies. You gain a +1 bonus to all saving throws for each totem you have granted to another creature.

sheet.description: You gain a +1 bonus to all saving throws for each totem you have granted to another creature.

description.p: Starting at 14th level, you have forged a direct connection with the life essence of the world around you. When you are forced to make a death saving throw at the start of your turn, you can instead spring back to your feet with a surge of healing energy. You immediately regain hit points equal to half your hit point maximum, and then you stand up if you so choose. A number of creatures of your choice equal to your Wisdom modifier (mimimum of 1), that are within 30 feet of you regain hit points equal to 2d10 + your Wisdom modifier.
Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

div.p: Witch-Doctors have the ability to grant other creatures the abilities of their shaman totems. When selecting the totems you wish to bestow upon another creature, remember that having the same ability from two sources does not stack.
For example, if you bestow the Totem of the Rockslide upon a monk with the Martial Arts feature, they must choose one unarmed strike calculation to use. They cannot use both.

sheet.description: When you are forced to make a death saving throw at the start of your turn, you can instead spring back to your feet with a surge of healing energy. You immediately regain half your hit points, and then you stand up if you so choose. Up to {{wis-mod:min-one}} creatures of your choice within 30 feet regain 2d10 + {{wisdom:modifier}} hit points.

description.p: When you deal damage to a creature, you can force them to make a Constitution saving throw against your shaman spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature cannot regain hit points until the beginning of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you deal damage to a creature, you can force them to make a Constitution saving throw against your shaman spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature cannot regain hit points until the beginning of your next turn.

description.p: Your unarmed attacks deal slashing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier on hit. If you aren’t wielding any weapons or a shield, the d6 becomes a d8.
Starting at 5th level, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistances.

description.p: While not wearing armor or using a shield your armor class is equal to 13 + your Constitution modifier.

description.p: Your base movement speed increases by 5 feet. This bonus to your movement speed increases to 10 feet at 7th level, and 15 feet at 15th level.
You can hold your breath for up to 1 hour while underwater. In addition, you develop a viscous coating on your skin that gives you advantage on ability checks to escape being grappled.

sheet.description: You have advantage on saving throws to resist being poisoned.

description.p: You gain proficiency in the Survival skill, and you have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track creatures while in natural environments.

sheet.description: You have advantage on Survival checks to track creatures while in natural environments.

description.p: Your eyes have adjusted to the darkness that comes after sundown. You gain Superior Darkvision to a range of 120 feet. Within that radius you can see in dim light as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light.

When an enemy creature hits you with a critical hit, you can use your reaction to change it into a regular hit. You can use this ability once, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest. Starting at 12th level, you can use this ability twice between a short or long rest.
